heisig_story: Under the familiar top hat we see a crisscross pattern or design, like that found on woodwork or garments. This should make an ugly enough image to help remember it. It can be associated with sentence by thinking of a sentence as a grammatical pattern.

WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for writing first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means writing as well.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Make sure you know those radicals, yo!
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic:
This kanji has more than one important reading you need to learn, sorry! But don't worry, here's a mnemonic to help you:
When you're writing you need things to fuel you. That's why you always eat buns (ã¶ã‚“) while you write. Bread bun, hot crossed buns, whatever as long as they're buns, they're great writing fuel.
When buns aren't enough, you call in the monster (ã‚‚ã‚“) that lives under your bed. It pretends to chase you, motivating your writing even further, because if you don't write fast, you'll die by monster bites.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Imagine shoveling buns into your mouth and running from a monster as you're writing. You're so determined! This is going to be the best thing you've ever written!

humanum_full_description_en:
The word "æ–‡" is like a pattern on the human body. Ancient and modern scholars refer to the original meaning of tattoos. " Wen " refers to tattoos, and there are many records in ancient books. Such as "Zhuangzi. "Xiaoyaoyou": "Vietnamese people have broken hair tattoos." "Book of Rites. "Wang Zhi": "The East is said to be barbarians, and they are tattooed." Kong Yingdashu: "Tattoos are said to be decorated with Danqingwen." From the oracle bone and gold characters of " Wen ", we can see that there are patterns on the chest of people who have always stood up. Among them, the heart shape is the most common, but there are also "cross" patterns or even dots. The "æ–‡" character in the Jiajin inscriptions also has the cross pattern completely omitted. Both the bamboo slips of the Warring States Period and the Xiaozhuan bear this shape. The word "æ–‡" in the bamboo books of the Shanghai Museum may be decorated with " kou ", which is different from " stingy ". See " stingy ". "Said Wen": "Writing, wrong drawing. It is like handing over to the text. All texts belong to the text." Although the language is simple, the referents are not far away.

The character "æ–‡" in the oracle bone inscriptions is used as the name of a person. "Compilation" 4611 reverses: "Wen enters ten", which means Wen Gong has ten (a piece of tortoise shell). Also used as a place name, "Collection" 27695: "Yuwenshi", referring to Yuwendi Zhushi. In addition, the word "Wenwu Ding" is often seen in oracle bone inscriptions, which is used as the title of the Shang dynasty. For example, "He Ji" 36134: "Wenwu Ding, Qi Lao" refers to the sacrifice of Wenwu Ding.

Bronze " wen " refers to beauty and goodness, and is often used as a respect for the ancestors, such as chasing ğ£ª•: "Use to enjoy filial piety to the ancestors." " Enjoy " refers to offering sacrifices to sacrifice to ancestors. The whole sentence refers to worship with sacrifices Ancestors of Germany. "book. "The Order of the Marquis of Wen": "Following filial piety to former scholars." The biography of Kong Anguo: "Enables to pursue filial piety to those of former Wende." It is also used to refer to Zhou Wenwang, Jichang, on the wall of history: "Yue Guwen Wang, early ğ¢¿ (ç›­) "He Yu Zheng" means that from the previous Zhou Wenwang, he started to govern political affairs with the goal of stability or harmony (Ma Chengyuan). Or used as posthumous titles, names of people or clan names.

The word "æ–‡" originally referred to the ornamentation painted on a person's body, and later used to refer to symbols in general, which extended the meaning of " text ". The " wen " of the bamboo slips of the Warring States Period is used as an article, "Shangbo Bamboo Book One. "Confucius Poetry Theory" Jane 1: "Writing death (no) hidden meaning" refers to the article has no idea of concealment.

" Text " even derives from the "word" the extremely abstract meanings of phenomena, symptoms, and affair shown by existing things. "Zhou Yi. Ben.å½–": "To observe the astronomy, to observe the time change; to observe the humanities, to transform into the world", that is to say, "astronomy" and "humanities" are opposed, which means that we can be in In the unpredictable environment, we know what we can do and adapt to the general. By mastering the behavior characteristics of personnel, we can practice education in the community.

The "Wen Wang" in "Shang Shu" was often mistaken for "Ning Wang" until Wang Yirong, Wu Dazhen and others used the word " Wen " in the ancient text to correct the word " Ning " in the ancient book.
humanum_short_description_en: The word "æ–‡" has a pattern on the body of a golden inscription, and the original meaning is a tattoo.

The kanji and the radical are the same, so remembering the meaning of this kanji is as simple as making sure you know the radical for writing first! If you know the radical, you know this kanji means writing as well.

This kanji has more than one important reading you need to learn, sorry! But don't worry, here's a mnemonic to help you:
When you're writing you need things to fuel you. That's why you always eat buns (ã¶ã‚“) while you write. Bread bun, hot crossed buns, whatever as long as they're buns, they're great writing fuel.
When buns aren't enough, you call in the monster (ã‚‚ã‚“) that lives under your bed. It pretends to chase you, motivating your writing even further, because if you don't write fast, you'll die by monster bites.
